item.title: Fallout Season Two Doesn't Just Go to New Vegas, It Builds On It
item.content:encoded:
This will contain spoilers for Fallout Season 1. Read at your own discretion.

Fallout Season One ended with Hank MacLean (Kyle MacLachlan) traveling to the city limits of the post-apocalyptic New Vegas, with Lucy (Ella Purnell) and Cooper Howard (Walton Goggins) in pursuit.

It was a cliffhanger engineered for fan service. Fallout: New Vegas is one of the series' most acclaimed entries, so returning to the Mojave Wasteland in Fallout Season Two would be an easy avenue for gamer nostalgia. It also led to an excited fan base wondering if the next season would answer lingering questions or definitively state which of the game's different endings were canon.

For me, however, I was worried. The secret sauce behind Jonathan Nolan and Kilter Films' adaptation is that it told its own stories, with all creative decisions being in conversation with the rich lore and history found in Bethesda's iconic series. So when I saw that distinct rusted city of sin, I was ready for the next season to be a lot of tedious walk-on cameos and unnecessary story cul-de-sacs.

Thankfully, that is not the case. Fallout Season Two continues to build on what came before, elevating the setting's dark satire, deepening character dynamics, and embodying one of New Vegas' most enduring messages about human nature.

Fallout Season Two – Odds Favor The House

In Fallout Season One, it was revealed that the nuclear war that ended the world wasn't the decision of nations, but by the executives of the largest companies in the world. Punctuated by Fallout's most iconic line, “war never changes.”

It has always been one of Fallout's boldest central messages. Despite being in an alternate world full of laser guns, super science, and robot helpers, the reasons why people kill each other remain the same. National pride. Religious dogma. Or in this world's case: the machinations of capitalism.

This critical eye towards unchecked corporate reach continues in Fallout Season Two with Robert House. While House is an established character from Fallout: New Vegas, it is nearly impossible not to draw parallels between his portrayal in the show and more contemporary corporate giants. He is the head of a massive robotics company, a self-styled genius that rejects emotion and sentiment, and is working on neural implants via unethical experimentation.

At one point early in the season, House states that he gained the consent of the world to go forward with these projects, explaining that every dollar spent on his work was a “vote” for him. It is a blunt criticism of the neoliberal market and a look at the horrifying world being built on the ashes of the old world. It's a parallel that could easily come off as hackneyed, but it aligns with the source material effortlessly.

This parallel persists in Fallout Season Two with the ongoing Vault-Tec storyline. Time and again, the show exposes the false meritocracy of the world's capitalist system. The lives preserved by the Vaults were not the best and brightest, but the wealthy and their sycophantic followers. This leads to darkly humorous moments where white-collar suits face the cruel reality they have enabled.

Fallout Season Two – New Vegas, Characters, and Canon

Fallout Season Two also deftly navigates the thematic trappings of Fallout: New Vegas with grace. As mentioned before in my review, Cooper Howard started as a dark subversion of the cowboy, a righteous Lone Ranger-type hero worn down into a sadistic murderer. However, this cruelty was all in service of Howard's one driving motivation: finding the cryo pods containing his wife and daughter.

With Howard now wandering the Mojave Wasteland, parallels can be drawn to Fallout: New Vegas' protagonist: the Courier. This player-controlled character goes on a Western-themed adventure, a vengeance quest against someone who left them for dead. But through their journey, the Courier brings some form of law or stability to the groups and places they encounter. While Howard has grown callous and cynical about the power of one person's choices, the Courier demonstrated just how much difference one person can make.

In a notable story development, it appears Howard is vindicated. Despite all of the fan theories, Fallout Season Two sidesteps addressing the “canon” ending of Fallout: New Vegas. A version of the game's events still happened, but were swiftly upended by the disruptive tactics of Season One's villains; a knock-on effect of the bombing of Shady Sands.

In the most cynical reading of the show, nothing the Courier did mattered. The Mojave is still a lawless wasteland. The various factions, like Caesar's Legion and the NCR, are still fighting and killing each other like they were before. War never changes.

Except that reading ignores one of New Vegas' most powerful final messages. At the end of the game's final expansion, Lonesome Road, a major character re-frames the haunting line in a new light. “If war doesn't change, men must change, and so must their symbols.”

It is a line that affirms the powerful sway of ideology and belief on human nature, and it resonates throughout Fallout Season Two. While the world is scarred by House and Vault-Tec, these actions are of the old guard. At key moments, idealism and conviction are what help the main cast question and even challenge these institutional ideas. It is seen everywhere with Howard's rekindled humanity and Lucy's optimism being refined.

This doesn't mean that Fallout Season Two doesn't indulge in some fan service. The show is peppered with familiar iconography and locations. There is pure visceral joy to see certain towns fully realized as actual sets. And it is a thrill to finally see Deathclaws on screen.

But, despite the temptation for hollow nostalgia, the focus of Fallout Season Two is where it needs to be: on its characters, and how they change through the roads they walk.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. This… More about Tyler
